div.l: A gylour shal him self bigylet be
And god that sitte hye in maieste
Saue all the compenye gret ⁊and smale
Thus haue I quyt the myller his tale
Here endeth the Reues tale
Here bygynneth the ꝓprolog of the Cookes tale
The Cook of london while the reue spak
For Ioye he thought he clawed on his bak
A ha ꝙquod he for cristes passyoun
This myller hath a sharp conclusyoıı̄un
Vpon his argument of herbigage
Wel seyde salamon in his langage
Brynge not euery mon vn to thyn hows
For herberewynge bi night is perelows
Wel oughte a man a vised for to be
Whom that he brought to his pryuete
I preye to god yeue sorowe ⁊and care
If euer seth I hette hogge of ware
Herde I a myller better set a werk
He had a Iape of malys in the derk
And therfore if you fouche saf to here
But god forbede we stynte here
A tale of me that am a pore man
I wol you telle as wel as I can
A lytel Iape that fell in our͗e cyte
¶ Oure ost seyde I graunte hit the
Now telle on Roger͗e loke that hit be good
For mony a past thou hast let blod
And mony a Iacke of douer hast thou sold
That hath be twyes hote ⁊and twyes cold
Of mony a pilgryme hast thou cristes cors
For of thi parcell yet fare I the wors
